Award.AwardTitle: CPS/Synergy/Collaborative Research: Cybernizing Mechanical Structures through Integrated Sensor-Structure Fabrication

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The timely and accurate in-service identification of faults in mechanical structures, such as airplanes, can play a vitally important role in avoiding catastrophes. One major challenge, however, is that the sensing system relies on high frequency signals, the coordination of which is difficult to achieve throughout a large structure. To tackle this fundamental issue, the research team will take advantage of 3D printing technology to fabricate integrated sensor-structure components. Specifically, the team plans to innovate a novel printing scheme that can embed piezoelectric transducers (namely, sensor/actuator coupled elements) into layered composites. As the transducers are densely distributed throughout the entire structure, they function like a nerve system embedded into the structure. Such a sensor nerve system, when combined with new control and command systems and advanced data and signal processing capability, can fully unleash the latest computing power to pinpoint the fault location.

The new framework of utilizing emerging additive manufacturing technology to produce a structural system with integrated, densely distributed active sensing elements will potentially lead to paradigm-shifting progress in structural self-diagnosis. This advancement may allow the acquisition of high-quality, active interrogation data throughout the entire structure, which can then be used to facilitate highly accurate and robust decision-making. It will lead to intellectual contributions including: 1) development of a new sensing modality with mechanical-electrical dual-field adaptivity, that yields rich and high-quality data throughout the structure; 2) design of an additive manufacturing scheme that inserts piezoelectric micro transducer arrays throughout the structure to enable active interrogation; and 3) formulation of new data analytics and inverse analysis that can accurately identify the fault location/severity and guide the fine-tuning of the sensor system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this collaborative project is new framework of cybernizing structural system for self-diagnosis.  The research team aims at synthesizing new sensing modality with piezoelectric transducers, designing new additive-manufacturing-enabled fabrication scheme that directly inserts sensing nerves throughout the structure; and formulating new data analytics and inverse analysis t to predict fault occurrence with high accuracy and robustness.  Specifically at University of Connecticut, our goals are 1) developing novel transducer array with electro-mechanical tuning capability that can effectively excite and at the same time sense high-frequency local oscillations within a structure; 2) calibrating transducer properties; 3) establishing first-principle-based transducer-circuit-structure interaction analysis to be incorporated in data analytics; and 4) demonstrate the system performance through self-diagnosis investigation and provide implementation guidance.  These goals are pursued in concurrent with those by the collaborative partners at Georgia Institute of Technology and Texas A&M University, which collectively lead to a new strategy of robust structural system integration. 

Throughout this project, at University of Connecticut, our major scientific progresses and outcomes include: 1) comprehensive modeling, design, and analysis of piezoelectric transducer arrays that can effectively guide ultrasonic wave propagation within a mechanical structure; 2) development of a variety of mechanisms in the mechanical and electrical domains to amplify the electro-mechanical coupling of piezoelectric transducer to enhance the wave manipulation performance; 3) formulation and validation of piezoelectric impedance/admittance based structural fault identification algorithms that take advantage of multi-objective optimization and computational intelligence; and 4) establishment of a comprehensive testbed that can experimentally investigate the performance of cybernized mechanical structure under various ambient conditions.  The outcomes of this research can play a significant role in facilitating intelligent structure with self-diagnosis capability for aerospace, marine, mechanical, transportation, and many other systems.  The collaborative nature of this research the interaction with industry provide students a multidisciplinary training environment.
